body: Instead of synchronously handling events as they happen in `tox_iterate`, this first collects all events in a structure and then lets the client process them. This allows clients to process events in parallel, since the data structure returned is mostly immutable. This also makes toxcore compatible with languages that don't (easily) support callbacks from C into the non-C language. If we remove the callbacks, this allows us to add fields to the events without breaking the API. --- This change is [](https://reviewable.io/reviews/toktok/c-toxcore/1952)

comment_data.body: There are some failures happening here that don't propagate up the stack. If we are not signaling failure, then perhaps at least log it? Also now that I think about it, this whole events module is lacking the logger.

comment_regular_data.body: You are saying that the returned buffers are made non-const specifically so that clients could steal them. Implying that const buffers can't be stolen. But isn't that implication false? non-const vs const only affects if the client is allowed to modify the buffer or not. The client can still take ownership of a buffer, i.e. steal (borrow?) it, even if it's const, until `tox_events_free` is called. So I'm not sure why you are implying otherwise. Maybe your definition of "steal" includes being able to modify the buffer?

> You are saying that the returned buffers are made non-const specifically so that clients could steal them. Implying that const buffers can't be stolen. But isn't that implication false? non-const vs const only affects if the client is allowed to modify the buffer or not. The client can still take ownership of a buffer, i.e. steal (borrow?) it, even if it's const, until `tox_events_free` is called. So I'm not sure why you are implying otherwise. Maybe your definition of "steal" includes being able to modify the buffer?

Fixed the comment.

commit.message:
feat: Add async event handling (callbacks) code.

Instead of synchronously handling events as they happen in
`tox_iterate`, this first collects all events in a structure and then
lets the client process them. This allows clients to process events in
parallel, since the data structure returned is mostly immutable.

This also makes toxcore compatible with languages that don't (easily)
support callbacks from C into the non-C language.

If we remove the callbacks, this allows us to add fields to the events
without breaking the API.

feat: Add async event handling (callbacks) code.

Instead of synchronously handling events as they happen in
`tox_iterate`, this first collects all events in a structure and then
lets the client process them. This allows clients to process events in
parallel, since the data structure returned is mostly immutable.

This also makes toxcore compatible with languages that don't (easily)
support callbacks from C into the non-C language.

If we remove the callbacks, this allows us to add fields to the events
without breaking the API.
